name: Hydrogen
p_(pa): vapor pressure, P (Pa), 1, 10, 100, 1 k, 10 k, 100 k, at T (K), 15, 20
desc: Hydrogen is an essential element for life. It is present in water and in almost all the molecules in living things. A colourless, odourless gas, It has the lowest density of all gases. Hydrogen can be added to fats and oils, such as peanut oil, through a process called hydrogenation.

name: Helium
appearance: colorless gas, exhibiting a red-orange glow when placed in a high-voltage electric field
p_(pa): vapor pressure (defined by ITS-90), P (Pa), 1, 10, 100, 1 k, 10 k, 100 k, at T (K), 1.23, 1.67, 2.48, 4.21
naming: after Helios, Greek god of the Sun
first_isolation: William Ramsay, Per Teodor Cleve, Abraham Langlet (1895)
desc: Helium is one of the noble gases of group O in the periodic table. It's the second lightest element. Helium gas is used to inflate blimps, scientific balloons and party balloons, also to inert shields for arc welding, to pressurize the fuel tanks of liquid fueled rockets and in supersonic wind tunnels.

name: Lithium
desc: The most important use of lithium is in rechargeable batteries for mobile phones, laptops, digital cameras and electric vehicles. Lithium is also used in some non-rechargeable batteries for things like heart pacemakers, toys and clocks. Lithium does not occur as the metal in nature, but is found combined in small amounts in nearly all igneous rocks and in the waters of many mineral springs.

name: Beryllium
desc: Beryllium is a silvery-white metal. It is relatively soft and has a low density. Beryllium is used in alloys with copper or nickel to make gyroscopes, springs, electrical contacts, spot-welding electrodes and non-sparking tools.

name: Boron
discovery: Joseph Louis Gay-Lussac and Louis Jacques Th�nard (30 June 1808)
desc: Pure boron is a dark amorphous powder. The most important compounds of boron are boric (or boracic) acid, borax (sodium borate) and boric oxide. These can be found in eye drops, mild antiseptics, washing powders and tile glazes.

name: Carbon
element_category: polyatomic nonmetal, sometimes considered a metalloid
density_near_rt: amorphous: 1.8�2.1 g/cm3, graphite: 2.267 g/cm3, diamond: 3.515 g/cm3
desc: There are a number of pure forms of this element including graphite, diamond, fullerenes and graphene. Diamond is a colourless, transparent, crystalline solid and the hardest known material. Graphite is black and shiny but soft. The nano-forms, fullerenes and graphene, appear as black or dark brown, soot-like powders.

name: Nitrogen
desc: A colourless, odourless gas, it is used to make fertilisers, nitric acid, nylon, dyes and explosives. It is used to make fertilisers, nitric acid, nylon, dyes and explosives, making nitrogen very important in the chemical industry. To make these products, nitrogen must first be reacted with hydrogen to produce ammonia.

name: Oxygen
p_(pa): vapor pressure, P (Pa), 1, 10, 100, 1 k, 10 k, 100 k, at T (K), 61, 73, 90
desc: A colourless, odourless gas, and the greatest commercial use of oxygen gas is in the steel industry. Oxygen first appeared in the Earth’s atmosphere around 2 billion years ago, accumulating from the photosynthesis of blue-green algae.

name: Fluorine
appearance:
gas: very pale yellow
liquid: bright yellow
solid: alpha is opaque, beta is transparent
naming: after the mineral fluorite, itself named after Latin fluo (to flow, in smelting)
desc: Very pale yellow-green, and dangerously reactive gas. It is the most reactive of all the elements and quickly attacks all metals, which made it a very useful tool during WWII, which was the first commercial use of fluorine, when developing the atom bomb, and other nuclear energy projects, made it necessary to produce large quantities.

name: Neon
appearance: colorless gas exhibiting an orange-red glow when placed in a high voltage electric field
desc: A colourless, odourless gas, neon will not react with any other substance. The largest use of neon is in making the ubiquitous ‘neon signs’ for advertising.

name: Sodium
desc: Sodium is a soft metal that tarnishes within seconds of being exposed to the air, and also reacts vigorously with water. Sodium is used as a heat exchanger in some nuclear reactors, and as a reagent in the chemicals industry

name: Magnesium
naming: after Magnesia, Greece
desc: A silvery-white metal that ignites easily in air and burns with a bright light. Magnesium is used in products that benefit from being lightweight, such as car seats, luggage, laptops, cameras and power tools. It is also added to molten iron and steel to remove sulfur.

name: Aluminum
element_category: post-transition metal, sometimes considered a metalloid
desc: Aluminium is a silvery-white, lightweight metal. It is soft and malleable. Aluminium is used in a huge variety of products including cans, foils, kitchen utensils, window frames, beer kegs and aeroplane parts. This is because of its particular properties. It has low density, is non-toxic, has a high thermal conductivity, has excellent corrosion resistance and can be easily cast, machined and formed.

name: Silicon
naming: after Latin 'silex' or 'silicis', meaning flint
desc: This element, when ultrapure, is a solid with a blue-grey metallic sheen. Silicon is one of the most useful elements to mankind. Most is used to make alloys including aluminium-silicon and ferrosilicon (iron-silicon). These are used to make dynamo and transformer plates, engine blocks, cylinder heads and machine tools and to deoxidise steel.

name: Phosphorus
appearance: colourless, waxy white, yellow, scarlet, red, violet, black
p_(pa):
vapour pressure (red, b.p. 431 �C)



P (Pa)
1
10
100
1 k
10 k
100 k


at T (K)
455
489
529
576
635
704
density_near_rt: white: 1.823 g�cm?3, red: ? 2.2�2.34 g�cm?3, violet: 2.36 g�cm?3, black: 2.69 g/cm3
desc: The two main forms of phosphorus are white phosphorus and red phosphorus. White phosphorus is a poisonous waxy solid and contact with skin can cause severe burns. It glows in the dark and is spontaneously flammable when exposed to air. Red phosphorus is an amorphous non-toxic solid. White phosphorus is used in flares and incendiary devices. Red phosphorus is in the material stuck on the side of matchboxes, used to strike safety matches against to light them.

name: Sulfur
density_near_rt: alpha: 2.07 g/cm3, beta: 1.96 g/cm3, gamma: 1.92 g/cm3
desc: here are several allotropes of sulfur. The most common appears as yellow crystals or powder. Sulfur is used in the vulcanisation of black rubber, as a fungicide and in black gunpowder. Most sulfur is, however, used in the production of sulfuric acid to make phosphates for fertilisers.

name: Chlorine
desc: A yellowy-green dense gas with a choking smell. Chlorine kills bacteria – it is a disinfectant. It is used to treat drinking water and swimming pool water. It is also used to make hundreds of consumer products from paper to paints, and from textiles to insecticides.

name: Argon
appearance: colorless gas exhibiting a lilac/violet glow when placed in a high voltage electric field
desc: Argon is a colourless, odourless gas that is totally inert to other substances. It is used in this way for the production of titanium and other reactive elements.

name: Potassium
desc: A soft, silvery metal that tarnishes in air within minutes. The greatest demand for potassium compounds is in fertilisers. Potassium is essential to life. Potassium ions are found in all cells. It is important for maintaining fluid and electrolyte balance.

name: Calcium
appearance: dull gray, silver; with a pale yellow tint
desc: Calcium is a silvery-white, soft metal that tarnishes rapidly in air and reacts with water. Calcium is essential to all living things, particularly for the growth of healthy teeth and bones. Calcium phosphate is the main component of bone. The average human contains about 1 kilogram of calcium.

name: Scandium
naming: after Scandinavia
desc: A silvery metal that tarnishes in air, burns easily and reacts with water. Scandium is mainly used for research purposes.

name: Titanium
desc: A hard, shiny and strong metal. Titanium is as strong as steel but much less dense. Titanium metal connects well with bone, so it has found surgical applications such as in joint replacements (especially hip joints) and tooth implants. Titanium has no known biological role, and is non-toxic.

name: Vanadium
desc: A silvery metal that resists corrosion. About 80% of the vanadium produced is used as a steel additive. Vanadium is essential to some species, including humans, although we need very little. We take in just 0.01 milligrams each day, and this is more than sufficient for our needs.

name: Chromium
oxidation_states: 6, 5, 4, 3, 2, 1, ?1, ?2, ?4 (depending on the oxidation state, an acidic, basic, or amphoteric oxide)
desc: A hard, silvery metal with a blue tinge. About 90% of all leather is tanned using chrome. However, the waste effluent is toxic so alternatives are being investigated. Chromium is an essential trace element for humans because it helps us to use glucose.

name: Manganese
oxidation_states: 7, 6, 5, 4, 3, 2, 1, ?1, ?2, ?3 acidic, basic or amphoteric; depending on the oxidation state
desc: A hard, brittle, silvery metal. Manganese is too brittle to be of much use as a pure metal. It is mainly used in alloys, such as steel. Drinks cans are made of an alloy of aluminium with 1.5% manganese, to improve resistance to corrosion. Manganese is an essential element in all known living organisms, because many types of enzymes contain manganese.

name: Iron
appearance: lustrous metallic with a grayish tinge
desc: A shiny, greyish metal that rusts in damp air. Iron is an enigma – it rusts easily, yet it is the most important of all metals; 90% of all metal that is refined today is iron.

name: Cobalt
desc: A lustrous, silvery-blue metal, and is magnetic. Cobalt, like iron, can be magnetised and so is used to make magnets. The amount we need is very small, and the body contains only about 1 milligram.

name: Nickel
appearance: lustrous, metallic, and silver with a gold tinge
desc: A silvery metal that resists corrosion even at high temperatures. It is mainly used in making alloys such as stainless steel. Nickel is used in batteries, and has a long history of being used in coins.

name: Copper
naming: after Cyprus, principal mining place in Roman era (Cyprium)
desc: A reddish-gold metal that is easily worked and drawn into wires. Historically, copper was the first metal to be worked by people. The discovery that it could be hardened with a little tin to form the alloy bronze gave the name to the Bronze Age. Copper is an essential element. An adult human needs around 1.2 milligrams of copper a day, to help enzymes transfer energy in cells. Excess copper is toxic. (Wilson’s disease) and other genetic diseases can affect the body’s ability to use copper.

name: Zinc
element_category: transition metal, alternatively considered a post-transition metal
desc: A silvery-white metal with a blue tinge, and tarnishes in air. Zinc is essential for all living things, forming the active site in over 20 metallo-enzymes. The average human body contains about 2.5 grams and takes in about 15 milligrams per day.

name: Gallium
naming: after Gallia (Latin for: France), homeland of the discoverer
desc: Gallium is a soft, silvery-white metal, similar to aluminium. Gallium arsenide has a similar structure to silicon and is a useful silicon substitute for the electronics industry. Gallium has no known biological role, and is non-toxic.

name: Germanium
naming: after Germany, homeland of the discoverer
desc: A silvery-white semi-metal, and is brittle. Germanium oxide has a high index of refraction and dispersion, making it suitable for use in wide-angle camera lenses and objective lenses for microscopes, which is now the major use for this element.

name: Arsenic
desc: Arsenic is a semi-metal. In its metallic form it is bright, silver-grey and brittle. Arsenic is a well-known poison. Arsenic compounds are sometimes used as rat poisons and insecticides but their use is strictly controlled. Some scientists think that arsenic may be an essential element in our diet in very, very low doses.

name: Selenium
appearance: black, red, and gray (not pictured) allotropes
element_category: polyatomic nonmetal, sometimes considered a metalloid
naming: after Selene, Greek goddess of the moon
density_near_rt: gray: 4.81 g/cm3, alpha: 4.39 g/cm3, vitreous: 4.28 g/cm3
discovery_and_first_isolation: J�ns Jakob Berzelius and Johann Gottlieb Gahn (1817)
desc: A semi-metal that can exist in two forms: as a silvery metal or as a red powder. The biggest use of selenium is as an additive to glass. Some selenium compounds decolourise glass, while others give a deep red colour. Selenium is an essential trace element for some species, including humans. Our bodies contain about 14 milligrams, and every cell in a human body contains more than a million selenium atoms.

name: Bromine
discovery_and_first_isolation: Antoine J�r�me Balard and Carl Jacob L�wig (1825)
desc: Bromine is a deep-red, oily liquid with a sharp smell, and is toxic. Bromine compounds can be used as flame retardants. They are added to furniture foam, plastic casings for electronics and textiles to make them less flammable. Bromine compounds can be used as flame retardants, and are added to furniture foam, plastic casings for electronics, and textiles to make them less flammable.

name: Krypton
appearance: colorless gas, exhibiting a whitish glow in a high electric field
desc: Krypton is a gas with no colour or smell. It does not react with anything except fluorine gas. Krypton is used commercially as a filling gas for energy-saving fluorescent lights, and used in some flash lamps used for high-speed photography.

name: Rubidium
desc: A soft metal that ignites in the air and reacts violently with water. Rubidium nitrate is sometimes used in fireworks to give them a purple colour. Rubidium has no known biological role and is non-toxic. However, because of its chemical similarity to potassium we absorb it from our food, and the average person has stores of about half a gram.

name: Strontium
appearance: silvery white metallic; with a pale yellow tint
naming: after the mineral strontianite, itself named after Strontian, Scotland
desc: A soft, silvery metal that burns in air and reacts with water. Strontium is best known for the reds its salts give to fireworks and flares. Modern ‘glow-in-the-dark’ paints and plastics contain strontium aluminate. They absorb light during the day and release it slowly for hours afterwards.

name: Yttrium
naming: after Ytterby, Sweden and its mineral ytterbite (gadolinite)
desc: A soft, silvery metal.  Yttrium-aluminium garnet is used in lasers that can cut through metals, also in white LED lights. Yttrium has no known biological role, and Its soluble salts are mildly toxic.

name: Zirconium
naming: after zircon, zargun ????? meaning "gold-colored".
desc: A hard, silvery metal that is very resistant to corrosion. Zirconium does not absorb neutrons, making it an ideal material for use in nuclear power stations.

name: Niobium
naming: after Niobe in Greek mythology, daughter of Tantalus (tantalum)
desc: A silvery metal that is very resistant to corrosion due to a layer of oxide on its surface. Niobium is used in alloys including stainless steel.

name: Molybdenum
desc: A shiny, silvery metal. Molybdenum has a very high melting point so it is produced and sold as a grey powder. Many molybdenum items are formed by compressing the powder at a very high pressure.

name: Technetium
desc: A radioactive, silvery metal that does not occur naturally. The gamma-ray emitting technetium-99m (metastable) is widely used for medical diagnostic studies. Several chemical forms are used to image different parts of the body

name: Ruthenium
naming: after Ruthenia (Latin for: medieval Kyivska Rus' region)
desc: A shiny, silvery metal. Most is used in the electronics industry for chip resistors and electrical contacts.

name: Rhodium
desc: A hard, shiny, silvery metal. The major use of rhodium is in catalytic converters for cars (80%). It reduces nitrogen oxides in exhaust gases.

name: Palladium
naming: after asteroid Pallas, itself named after Pallas Athena
desc: A shiny, silvery-white metal that resists corrosion. Most palladium is used in catalytic converters for cars. It is also used in jewellery and some dental fillings and crowns.

name: Silver
desc: Silver is a relatively soft, shiny metal. It tarnishes slowly in air as sulfur compounds react with the surface forming black silver sulfide. Silver is used to make mirrors, as it is the best reflector of visible light known, although it does tarnish with time. It is also used in dental alloys, solder and brazing alloys, electrical contacts and batteries. Silver paints are used for making printed circuits.

name: Cadmium
element_category: transition metal, alternatively considered a post-transition metal
discovery_and_first_isolation: Karl Samuel Leberecht Hermann and Friedrich Stromeyer (1817)
desc: Cadmium is a silvery metal with a bluish tinge to its surface. 80% of cadmium currently produced is used in rechargeable nickel-cadmium batteries.

name: Indium
discovery: Ferdinand Reich and Hieronymous Theodor Richter (1863)
desc: A soft, silvery metal that is stable in air and water. Most indium is used to make indium tin oxide (ITO), which is an important part of touch screens, flatscreen TVs and solar panels.

name: Tin
desc: A soft, pliable metal. Below 13°C it slowly changes to a powder form. Most window glass is made by floating molten glass on molten tin to produce a flat surface.

name: Antimony
desc: Antimony is a semi-metal. In its metallic form it is silvery, hard and brittle. Antimony is used in the electronics industry to make some semiconductor devices, such as infrared detectors and diodes.

name: Tellurium
naming: after Roman Tellus, deity of the Earth
desc: A semi-metal usually obtained as a grey powder. Tellurium has been used to vulcanise rubber, to tint glass and ceramics, in solar cells, in rewritable CDs and DVDs

name: Iodine
appearance: lustrous metallic gray, violet as a gas
desc: A black, shiny, crystalline solid. When heated, iodine sublimes to form a purple vapour. Photography was the first commercial use for iodine after Louis Daguerre, in 1839, invented a technique for producing images on a piece of metal.

name: Xenon
appearance: colorless gas, exhibiting a blue glow when placed in a high voltage electric field
oxidation_states: 0, +1, +2, +4, +6, +8 (rarely more than 0; a weakly acidic oxide)
desc: A colourless, odourless gas. It is very unreactive. Xenon is used in certain specialised light sources. It produces a beautiful blue glow when excited by an electrical discharge.

name: Cesium
naming: from Latin caesius, sky blue, for its spectral colours
desc: Caesium is a soft, gold-coloured metal that is quickly attacked by air and reacts explosively in water. The most common use for caesium compounds is as a drilling fluid.

name: Barium
appearance: silvery gray; with a pale yellow tint
desc: Barium is a soft, silvery metal that rapidly tarnishes in air and reacts with water. All barium compounds are toxic; however, barium sulfate is insoluble and so can be safely swallowed.

name: Lanthanum
element_category: lanthanide, sometimes considered a transition metal
desc: A soft, silvery-white metal. It rapidly tarnishes in air and burns easily when ignited. Lanthanum metal has no commercial uses.

name: Cerium
discovery: Martin Heinrich Klaproth, J�ns Jakob Berzelius, Wilhelm Hisinger (1803)
naming: after dwarf planet Ceres, itself named after Roman deity of agriculture Ceres
desc: Cerium is a grey metal. It is little used because it tarnishes easily, reacts with water and burns when heated. The best-known use for this alloy is in ‘flints’ for cigarette lighters. This is because cerium will make sparks when struck.

name: Praseodymium
desc: A soft, silvery metal. Praseodymium is used in a variety of alloys. The high-strength alloy it forms with magnesium is used in aircraft engines.

name: Neodymium
desc: Neodymium is a common earth metal that, along with praseodymium (Pr), was extracted from the mixture didymium; all bear the suffix “dym”, meaning “twin”.

name: Promethium
discovery: Chien Shiung Wu, Emilio Segr�, Hans Bethe (1942)
first_isolation: Charles D. Coryell, Jacob A. Marinsky, Lawrence E. Glendenin, Harold G. Richter (1945)
desc: Promethium is a highly radioactive and apparently-dangerous element that is usually sourced from uranium.

name: Samarium
naming: after the mineral samarskite (itself named after Vasili Samarsky-Bykhovets)
desc: Named tangentially after a Russian mining engineer, samarium has applications in the production of specialized magnets and (when radioactive) the treatment of several cancers.

name: Europium
appearance: silvery white, with a pale yellow tint; but rarely seen without oxide discoloration
naming: after Europe
desc: Europium is among the other especially-abundant elements isolated from common earth minerals, but is notable for being comparatively non-toxic.

name: Gadolinium
naming: after the mineral Gadolinite (itself named after Johan Gadolin)
desc: Gadolinium is a toxic earth metal, significant for decreasing the oxidation rates of some other metals when present in the same minerals.

name: Terbium
naming: after Ytterby (Sweden), where it was mined
desc: Terbium shares its namesake with Yttrium, and most of its practical applications lie in the technology and computing sector.

name: Dysprosium
desc: Dysprosium, interestingly, is notable for having very few applications that aren’t already shared by other, easier-to-obtain elements.

name: Holmium
desc: Holmium has the highest magnetic permeability--or ability to form a magnetic field around itself--of any thus-discovered element.

name: Erbium
naming: after Ytterby (Sweden), where it was mined
desc: Erbium is most recognized for certain ion ranges which magnify light and amplify lasers.

name: Thulium
naming: after Thule, a mythical region in Scandinavia
desc: Thulium, like other elements in its series, is almost always found in common minerals, and never in pure form.

name: Ytterbium
appearance: silvery white; with a pale yellow tint
naming: after Ytterby (Sweden), where it was mined
desc: Ytterbium, the fourth element named after Ytterby, is notable for powering the most stable atomic clock as of 2013.

name: Lutetium
element_category: lanthanide, sometimes considered a transition metal
naming: after Lutetia, Latin for: Paris, in the Roman era
desc: Lutetium’s discovery in 1907, alongside Ytterbium, was contested by three western scientists, with the credit being assigned to Frenchman Georges Urbain.

name: Hafnium
naming: after Hafnia. Latin for: Copenhagen, where it was discovered
discovery_and_first_isolation: Dirk Coster and George de Hevesy (1922)
desc: Hafnium is a transition metal which lacks many practical applications, because the more-abundant zirconium (Zr) often shares utility.

name: Tantalum
desc: Tantalum is used in powdered form in the production of computer parts, and is found in “coltan” ore, abundant in conflict zones in central Africa.

name: Tungsten
first_isolation: Juan Jos� Elhuyar and Fausto Elhuyar (1783)
desc: Sometimes called wolfram, tungsten is abundant in the ore wolframite. Portugal is its main producer in Europe, and this made it a center of political intrigue during the Second World War.

name: Rhenium
named_by: Walter Noddack, Ida Noddack, Otto Berg (1922)
naming: after the river Rhine (German: Rhein)
desc: Rhenium is among the rarest elements occurring naturally in the Earth’s crust, at approx. 1 parts per billion (ppb).

name: Osmium
desc: Osmium is the densest stable element, roughly twice as dense as lead (Pb).

name: Iridium
desc: Iridium is notable for being the most corrosion-resistant metal, untarnished at even 3000 degrees Celsius (3632 degrees Fahrenheit).

name: Platinum
desc: Platinum is the namesake of the “platinum group,” also including osmium (Os) and and iridium (Ir).

name: Gold
naming: from Latin aurum, meaning gold
desc: Gold is one of the elements most widely recognized for its value, for its rarity, ease of shaping and corrosion resistance.

name: Mercury
element_category: transition metal, alternatively considered a post-transition metal
desc: Mercury is the only metallic element that is in liquid form under standard conditions (0 degrees Celsius and normal pressure).

name: Thallium
desc: Thallium is highly toxic; when first discovered, it was used for pest control and insecticides before being phased out amid safety concerns.

name: Lead
desc: Pencils were never made from lead. You’ve been mis-lead.

name: Bismuth
desc: Bismuth is primarily used in pharmaceuticals, and is part of the mixture forming the active ingredient for Pepto-Bismol.

name: Polonium
element_category: post-transition metal, but this status is disputed
naming: after Polonia, Latin for Poland, homeland of Marie Curie
desc: Polonium was identified by the Curies due to its especially high radioactivity. All of its practical applications are rooted in this radioactivity.

name: Astatine
element_category: metalloid, sometimes classified as a nonmetal, or a metal
discovery: Dale R. Corson, Kenneth Ross MacKenzie, Emilio Segr� (1940)
naming: after Greek astatos (???????), meaning "unstable"
desc: Astatine is the rarest naturally-occurring element, and is so radioactive that it cannot be obtained in macroscopic samples.

name: Radon
appearance: colorless gas, occasionally glows green or red in discharge tubes
discovery: Ernest Rutherford and Robert B. Owens (1899)
desc: Radon is a radioactive noble gas which forms an especially significant hazard due to it being otherwise colorless, odorless and tasteless.

name: Francium
p_(pa): vapor pressure (extrapolated), P (Pa), 1, 10, 100, 1 k, 10 k, 100 k, at T (K), 404, 454, 519, 608, 738, 946
naming: after France, homeland of the discoverer
desc: With a half-life of less than half an hour, francium is among the most unstable elements that occur naturally.

name: Radium
oxidation_states: 2 (expected to have a strongly basic oxide)
desc: The traditional unit of measurement for radioactivity, the curie, is based off of a common isotope of radium.

name: Actinium
appearance: silvery-white, glowing with an eerie blue light; sometimes with a golden cast
element_category: actinide, sometimes considered a transition metal
desc: Actinium lacks industrial utility because of its rarity, its high price, and the danger posed by its radioactivity.

name: Thorium
desc: Thorium metal is silvery and tarnishes black when exposed to air. It is mainly used in electronics, but can be used for power generation

name: Protactinium
discovery_and_first_isolation: Kasimir Fajans and Oswald Helmuth G�hring (1913)
desc: Protactinium’s primary use is in radiometric dating, and despite its rarity in natural occurrence, it is produced as a byproduct of thorium in nuclear reactors.

name: Uranium
appearance: silvery gray metallic; corrodes to a spalling black oxide coat in air
naming: after planet Uranus, itself named after Greek god of the sky Uranus
desc: Uranium is an actinide used in high-density penetrators and vehicle armor in the military sector.

name: Neptunium
p_(pa): vapor pressure, P (Pa), 1, 10, 100, 1 k, 10 k, 100 k, at T (K), 2194, 2437
discovery: Edwin McMillan and Philip H. Abelson (1940)
naming: after planet Neptune, itself named after Roman god of the sea Neptune
density_near_rt: alpha: 20.45 g/cm3, accepted standard value: 19.38 g/cm3
desc: Neptunium is the first in the series of transuranic elements (93-118), all of which are very unstable and rapidly decay into other elements.

name: Plutonium
appearance: silvery white, tarnishing to dark gray in air
discovery: Glenn T. Seaborg, Arthur Wahl, Joseph W. Kennedy, Edwin McMillan (1940�1)
naming: after dwarf planet Pluto, itself named after classical god of the underworld Pluto
desc: Isotopes of plutonium are valuable fissure components in nuclear weaponry. The atomic bomb dropped on Nagasaki, Fat Man, had a plutonium core.

name: Americium
p_(pa): vapor pressure, P (Pa), 1, 10, 100, 1 k, 10 k, 100 k, at T (K), 1239, 1356
discovery: Glenn T. Seaborg, Ralph A. James, Leon O. Morgan, Albert Ghiorso (1944)
naming: after the Americas
desc: Americium, for America, is named for its sharing the same periodic group as Europium, for Europe.

name: Curium
appearance: silvery metallic, glows purple in the dark
p_(pa): vapor pressure, P (Pa), 1, 10, 100, 1 k, 10 k, 100 k, at T (K), 1788, 1982
discovery: Glenn T. Seaborg, Ralph A. James, Albert Ghiorso (1944)
naming: named after Marie Sk?odowska-Curie and Pierre Curie
desc: Curium, named for Marie and Pierre Curie, is used primarily for X-ray spectrometers on space probes.

name: Berkelium
naming: after Berkeley, California, where it was discovered
desc: Berkelium’s unique nuclear fission properties lead it to perform poorly in nuclear reactors compared to sibling elements like curium and californium.

name: Californium
naming: after California, where it was discovered
desc: Californium does not occur naturally; its only presence in the environment is in traces near chemical or medical facilities which expel it.

name: Einsteinium
appearance: silvery; glows blue in the dark
naming: after Albert Einstein
desc: Einsteinium, along with fermium, was first discovered in the fallout of American nuclear bomb tests immediately following the Second World War.

name: Fermium
naming: after Enrico Fermi
desc: Fermium, along with einsteinium, was first discovered in the fallout of American nuclear bomb tests immediately following the Second World War.

name: Mendelevium
naming: after Dmitri Mendeleev
desc: The American team responsible for synthesizing mendelevium had to ask the Cold War-era United States government for permission to name the element after Dmitri Mendeleev, a Russian.

name: Nobelium
naming: after Alfred Nobel
desc: The identification of nobelium, and the right to name it, was disputed by various international teams; “nobelium” was originally meant as a placeholder, but only nearly three decades later in 1994 was identification credit attributed to Soviet scientists (but the name remained).

name: Lawrencium
element_category: actinide, sometimes considered a transition metal
discovery: Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory and Joint Institute for Nuclear Research (1961�1971)
naming: after Ernest Lawrence
desc: Lawrencium was named for Ernest Lawrence, who invented the cyclotron, a chemical bombardment device responsible for the synthesis of some artificial transuranic elements.

name: Rutherfordium
desc: Rutherfordium was the center of a naming dispute between American scientists at Lawrence Berkeley and Russian scientists at Dubna, which would go unsettled until the Russian team conceded to end the dispute.

name: Dubnium
naming: after the town of Dubna in Russia
desc: The name “dubnium” was originally chosen as a compromise placeholder for the element that would later be named rutherfordium (Rf) amid a naming dispute.

name: Seaborgium
naming: after Glenn T. Seaborg
desc: Seaborgium was the center of controversy in the chemist community, because the International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry (IUPAC) initially rejected the name because its namesake, Glenn Seaborg, was still alive at the time of its discovery.

name: Bohrium
naming: after Niels Bohr
desc: Bohrium is named for Danish physicist Niels Bohr, recipient of the 1922 Nobel Prize in Physics and considered important for developing the Bohr model of the atom, which conceptualized the concept of electrons switching energy levels.

name: Hassium
naming: after Hassia, Latin for Hesse, Germany, where it was discovered
desc: A Soviet scientist claimed to have discovered naturally-occurring hassium (a synthetic element) in 1963, but a Joint Institute for Nuclear Research investigation in 2004 conducted a worldwide investigation that did not support these claims.

name: Meitnerium
element_category: unknown, but probably a transition metal
naming: after Lise Meitner
desc: Meitnerium is incredibly unstable, with its most stable isotope having a half-life of less than eight seconds.

name: Darmstadtium
element_category: unknown, but probably a transition metal
naming: after Darmstadt, Germany, where it was discovered
desc: Darmstadtium is named for Darmstadt, Germany, the site of its synthesis and the synthesis of many other synthetic transuranic elements.

name: Roentgenium
element_category: unknown, but probably a transition metal
naming: after Wilhelm R�ntgen
desc: Roentgenium was originally known as unununium (Uuu) under IUPAC professional guidelines, but like other elements outlined in these guidelines, most professionals referred to it numerically (“element 111,” or just “111”).

name: Copernicium
element_category: transition metal, alternatively considered a post-transition metal
naming: after Nicolaus Copernicus
desc: Copernicium’s synthesis by the same Darmstadt team responsible for darmstadtium was contested by the IUPAC, and the team had to retrace experiments and contest apparently-incorrect data in the investigation before their claim was finally recognized in 2009.

name: Nihonium
element_category: unknown, but probably a post-transition metal
discovery:
RIKEN (2004, first undisputed)
Joint Institute for Nuclear Research and Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory (2003, first announced)
naming: IUPAC systematic element name
desc: Nihonium, named for the Japanese word for “Japan”, was created in 2007 by a Japanese science team at Riken, a research institute spread across seven different campuses on the island.

name: Flerovium
discovery: Joint Institute for Nuclear Research (JINR) and Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory (LLNL) (1999)
naming: after Flerov Laboratory of Nuclear Reactions (itself named after Georgy Flyorov)
desc: Flerovium’s predicted properties suggest similar behavior to that of many noble gases, and it is hypothesized that it may be in a gaseous state under standard conditions (0 degrees Celsius and in a regular pressure environment).

name: Moscovium
element_category: unknown, but probably a post-transition metal
discovery: Joint Institute for Nuclear Research and Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory (2003)
naming: IUPAC systematic element name
desc: In the 1980s and 1990’s prior to its naming, moscovium, or “element 115”, was the center of a conspiracy theory by a man named Bob Lazar, who claimed it functioned as a “gravity wave generator” for flying saucers.

name: Livermorium
element_category: unknown, but probably a post-transition metal
discovery: Joint Institute for Nuclear Research and Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory (2000)
naming: after Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, itself named partly after Livermore, California
desc: Livermorium was named for the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, an American institute which collaborated with Russian chemists in Dubna to synthesize the element.

name: Tennessine
element_category: unknown, but probably a post-transition metal
discovery: Joint Institute for Nuclear Research and Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory (2010)
naming: IUPAC systematic element name
desc: Tennessine was synthesized in another joint collaboration between American and Russian teams, by fusing berkelium (element 97) and calcium (element 20); the synthesis was almost hampered completely when Russian customs officials refused to receive the cooled berkelium due to paperwork issues.

name: Oganesson
element_category: unknown, but predicted to be a noble gas
discovery: Joint Institute for Nuclear Research and Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory (2002)
naming: IUPAC systematic element name
desc: Oganesson’s synthesis was initially claimed by Lawrence Berkeley scientists in 2002, but they quietly retracted their claim when they and other independent laboratories could not reproduce the results of the experiment.
